title-group.article-title: Stochastic model of reliability for use in the evaluation of the economic impact of a failure using life cycle cost analysis. Case studies on the rail freight and oil industries

article-meta.aff: 1Department Industrial Management School of Engineering, University of Seville, Spain
2Department of Industrial Engineering, University Federico Santa María, Chile

author-notes.corresp: Fredy Kristjanpoller, Department of Industrial Engineering, University Federico Santa María, Av. Espana 1680 Valparaiso, Chile. Email: fredy.kristjanpoller@usm.cl

abstract.p: This paper aims to investigate the technical and economic factors related to failure costs (non-reliability costs) within the life cycle cost analysis (LCCA) of a production asset. Life cycle costing is a well-established method for the evaluation of alternative asset options. It is a structured approach that addresses all the elements of this cost and can be used to produce a spend profile for an asset over its anticipated life-span. The results of an LCCA are used to assist management in the decision-making process when there is a choice of options. The main costs can be classified as the capital expenditure incurred when the asset is purchased, and the operating expenditure incurred during the asset’s life. This paper explores different aspects related to the failure costs within the LCCA, and describes the most important aspects of the stochastic model: a non-homogeneous Poisson process. This model is used to estimate the frequency of failures and their impact which can cause various failures in the total costs of a production asset. This paper also contains a case study for the rail freight industry (Chile) and the oil industry (Petronox, Venezuela) where the proposed model and concepts are applied, and respectively compared in terms of results. Finally, the presented model provides maintenance managers with a decision tool that optimizes the LCCA of an asset and increases the efficiency of the decision-making process related to the control of failures.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the objective of optimizing costs and improving the profitability of production processes, companies in the World Class category1 dedicate enormous efforts to visualize, analyse, implement and execute strategies for the solution of problems. This involves making decisions in high impact areas such as security, environment, production goals, product quality, operation costs and maintenance. In recent years, specialists in the areas of value engineering and operations direction have focused attention on the asset management field, due to the great opportunities for improvements that it presents. One of the most interesting challenges is to improve the quantification process of costs, including the use of techniques that quantify the reliability factor and the impact of failure events on the total cost of a production system throughout its life cycle.2 These improvements have lessened the uncertainty in the process of decision making in vitally important areas such as design, development, maintenance, substitution and acquisition of production assets. It should be noted that this process consists of many decisions and actions, technical as well as non-technical, that should be considered over the whole period of use of an industrial asset. Product support and maintenance needs of systems are more or less decided during the design and manufacturing phase,3 but they have a great impact over all the duration of an asset’s life that can be studied using life cycle cost analysis (LCCA).

Most of the considered actions, particularly those that correspond to the design phase of the production system, have a high impact on the total life cycle of the asset. Of particular interest are decisions related to the improvement process of the reliability factor (quality of the design, technology used, technical complexity, frequency of failures, cost of preventive/corrective maintenance, maintainability levels and accessibility), since these aspects have a major influence on the total cost of the asset’s life cycle, and they influence to a significant extent the opportunity to extend the useful life of the production systems at reasonable costs.3–8 The traditional methodologies used to estimate the LCCA utilize average behaviour; therefore, it is necessary to search for an application that can model degradation effects in order to have a more realistic analysis that can be used to generate the right asset management strategy.

sec.title: Basic aspects of LCCA
sec.p: In recent years LCCA has continued to develop both on the academic level as well as on the industrial level. It is important to mention the existence of other methodologies that have emerged in the area of LCCA, such as life cycle costs analysis and environmental impact, total costs analysis of production assets, among others.9

These methodologies each have their own particular characteristics, although regarding the estimation process of the costs for the impact of failure events; they usually propose reliability-analysis-based constant failures rates. The early implementation of cost analysis techniques allows for early evaluation of potential design problems and the quantification of their potential impact on the cost during the life cycle of an industrial asset.9 For this, procedures exist that group together to form the LCCA technique. LCCA is defined as an economic calculation technique which supports optimal decision making and is linked to design process, selection, development and substitution of the assets in a production system.10 It, ideally, evaluates the costs associated with the economic period of the expected useful life in a quantitative way, expressed in yearly equivalent monetary units (dollars/year, euros/year, pesos/year). Another definition states that LCCA is a systematic process of technical–economic evaluation, applied in the selection and replacement process of production systems that allows it to consider economics and reliability aspects in simultaneous manner, with the purpose of quantifying the real impact of all costs during the life cycle of the assets ($/year), and in this way, be able to select the asset that contributes the largest benefits to the productive system.11

The large number of variables that directly and indirectly affect the real costs (inflation, rise/decrease of the costs, reduction/increase in purchasing power, budget limitations, increase in the levels of competition and other similar characteristics), must be managed to allow accurate estimation of the real costs of an asset during its useful life. These characteristics of the model generate a scenario with high levels of uncertainty9 while at the same time generate interest about the total cost of the assets. Often, the total cost of the production system is not visible, in particular those costs associated with operation, maintenance, installation tests, operator training, among others. Additionally, the dynamic nature of the economic scenario generates problems related to the real determination of the asset’s cost. Some of the major problems are as follows.12

list-item.p: The cost factors are usually applied incorrectly. The individual costs are inadequately identified and, many times, they are included in the wrong category: the variable costs are treated as fixed (and vice versa); the indirect costs are treated as direct, etc.

The countable procedures do not always allow a realistic and timely evaluation of the total cost. In addition, it is often difficult (if not impossible) to determine the costs, according to a functional base.
Many times the budgetary practices are inflexible with regard to change of funds from one category to another, or, from one year to another.

sec.title: Characteristics of the costs in a production asset
sec.p: The cost of a life cycle is determined by identifying the applicable functions in each one of its phases, calculating the cost of these functions and applying the appropriate costs during the whole length of the life cycle. Thus, the cost of the life cycle should include all the costs incurred in the design, fabrication and production processes.13 The characteristics of the costs in the different phases of an asset’s life cycle can be summarized as follows.14

list-item.p: Investigation, design and development costs: initial planning, market analysis, product investigation, design and engineering requirements, etc.

Production, acquisition and construction costs: industrial engineering and analysis of operations, production (manufacturing, assembly and tests), construction of facilities, process development, production operations, quality control and initial requirements of logistics support.

Operation and support costs: operation inputs of the production system, planned maintenance, corrective maintenance (depend on the reliability factor) and costs of logistical support during the system’s life cycle.
Removal and elimination costs: elimination of non-repairable elements during the life cycle, retirement of the system and recycling material.

sec.p: From the financial point of view, the costs generated during the life cycle of the asset are classified into two types of costs.

list-item.p: CAPEX: capital costs (design, development, acquisition, installation, staff training, manuals, documentation, tools and facilities for maintenance, replacement parts, withdrawal).
OPEX: operational costs: (manpower, operations, planned maintenance, storage, recruiting and corrective maintenance – penalizations for failure events / low reliability).

sec.title: Impact of reliability on the LCCA
sec.p: Woodhouse11 states that to be able to design an efficient and competitive productive system in the modern industrial environment, it is necessary to both evaluate and quantify in a detailed way the following two aspects.

list-item.p: Costs: the aspect that is related to all the costs associated with the expected total life cycle of the production system. Including design costs, production, logistics, development, construction, operation, preventative/corrective maintenance, withdrawal.

Reliability: the factor that allows the prediction of the form in which the production processes can lose their operational continuity due to unforseen failures and to evaluate the impact on the costs that these failures cause in security, environment, operations and production.

sec.p: The key aspect of reliability is related to operational continuity. In other words, it is possible to affirm that a production system is reliable when it is able to accomplish its function in a secure and efficient way along its life cycle. If a production process begins to be affected by a large number of unexpected failure events (low reliability), this scenario causes high costs, associated mainly with the recovery of the function (direct costs) and with growing impact in the production process (penalization costs). sec.p: According to Woodhouse11 an increase in costs is caused, to a great extent, by the lack of a forecast of the occurrence of unexpected failures, a scenario provoked by ignorance and lack of analysis in the design phase of the aspects related with reliability. As a result, this situation causes an increase in the operation costs (costs that were not considered at the start) affecting the profitability of the production process.

This paper aims to investigate technical and economic factors related to failure costs (non-reliability costs) within the LCCA of a production asset. To avoid uncertainty in the cost analysis, studies on economic viability should consider all the aspects of the life cycle cost. The tendency of variability in the main economic factors, together with the already defined additional problems generally lead to erroneous estimates, causing design and development of production systems that are not suitable from a cost–benefit viewpoint.12 It can be anticipated that these conditions will worsen unless design engineers start to consider these costs. As a result of the dynamic changes in a process, the acquisition costs associated with the new systems are not the only ones to increase, the operation and maintenance costs of the systems already in use also rapidly increase. This is due to a combination of the following factors.12

list-item.p: Inaccuracies in the estimates, predictions and forecasts of the failure events (reliability), ignorance of the probability of occurrence of the different failure events inside the production systems in the evaluation.
Ignorance of the deterioration behaviour of processes.
Lack of forecasts on maintenance processes and ignorance of the modern techniques of maintenance management.
Engineering changes during the design and development phases.
Changes in the construction of the system.
Changes in expected production patterns.
Changes during the acquisition of system components.
Setbacks and unexpected problems.

sec.p: It is important to mention that the results obtained from the LCCA, reach their maximum effectiveness during the phases of: initial development, visualization, and conceptual, basic and details engineering. Once the design has been completed, it is very difficult to modify the economic results. Also, the economic considerations related to the life cycle should be specifically outlined during the phases previously mentioned, if the goal is to take advantage of effective economic engineering. It is necessary to keep in mind that almost two-thirds of the life cycle cost of an asset or system are determined in the preliminary conceptual and design phase (70-85% of value creation and costs reduction opportunities).17

sec.title: Main stochastic model considered for the analysis of reliability
sec.p: For this research, the application of LCCA must consider technical aspects related with the failure behaviour, performance function or information related to the asset deterioration. According to this framework, it will be necessary to use a stochastic technique, i.e. model that will support the assessment and calculation in the life-cycle cost.

The most important stochastic modelling approaches for the conditions of repairable or non-repairable systems will be reviewed in the next section. The technical characteristic is another important aspect, considered in the study for modelling and LCCA calculation.

sec.title: General review of stochastic modelling
sec.p: A non-repairable system is defined as: when it fails, it is discarded (a repair is physically infeasible or non-economic)18 so, in this case the most important concept will be survival probability. The times between failures of a non-repairable system are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.).19 This is the most common assumption made when analysing time-to-failure data, but in some situations, it might be unrealistic. The non-repairable methodologies used to analyse this scenario are generally statistical distribution fitting approaches such as Weibull analysis.20

Conversely, repairable systems are those that can be restored to their fully operational state, and thus the replacement of the entire system is not considered as a solution.21 In this sense, reliability is interpreted as the probability of not failing in a particular period t. In this case, this analysis does not assume that the times between failures are independent or identically distributed, and it is necessary to model the reliability using stochastic point processes. The number of failures in an interval of time can be represented through a stochastic point process. It can be interpreted as a counting process, and what it counts is the number of events (failures) in a certain period of time.
Focusing on the repairable systems, five main stochastic models exist:21

list-item.p: the renewal process (RP);
the homogeneous Poisson process (HPP);
the branching Poisson process (BPP);
the superposed renewal process (SRP);
the non-homogeneous Poisson process (NHPP).

sec.p: The RP model assumes that the system is returned to an ‘as new’ condition every time it is repaired, so it is conceptually similar to a non-repairable system approach in which the time to the failure can be modelled by a statistical distribution and the i.i.d. assumption is valid (see Figure 2). The HPP is a special case of the RP, which assumes that the times between failures are independent and identically exponentially distributed, so the i.i.d. assumption is also valid, and the time to failure is described by an exponential distribution (constant hazard rate).18 Variations of the RP can also be defined. The modified renewal process, where the first inter-arrival time differs from the others, and the superimposed renewal process (union of many independent RPs) are examples of possible variations.21

caption.p: Basic notation for a stochastic point process.

sec.p: The BPP is used to represent time-to-failure data that can be assumed to be identically distributed, but not independent. As Ascher and Feingold21 mention, this process is applicable when a primary failure (or a sequence of primary failures having i.i.d. times to failure) can trigger one or more subsidiary failures; thus there is dependence between the subsidiary failures and the occurrence of the primary, triggering failure. Very few practical applications of this model are found in the literature. More details about this process can be found in Rigdon and Basu. 22

The SRP is a process derived from the combination of various independent RPs (subcomponents of the main asset), and in general it is not an RP. Each subcomponent can be modelled as an RP, and then the system can be modelled using an SRP.23 In addition, the superposition of independent RPs converges to a Poisson process (possibly non-homogeneous), when the number of superimposed processes grows.24

When the repair or substitution of the failed part in a complex system does not involve a significant modification of the reliability of the equipment as a result of the repair action, the NHPP is able to correctly describe the failure and repair process. The NHPP can be interpreted as a minimal repair model25 which assumes that the unit returns to an ‘as bad as old’ condition after a repair. The NHPP differs from the HPP in that the rate of occurrence of failures varies with time rather than being constant.21 Unlike the previous model, in this process the inter-arrival times are neither independent nor identically distributed.
Another common classification for repairable systems is to consider that it may end up in one of the following five possible states after a repair:

list-item.p: as good as new;
as bad as old;
better than old, but worse than new;
better than new;
worse than old.

sec.p: The RP and NHPP account for the first two states, respectively. However, the last three repair states have received less attention since they involve more complex mathematical models. Kijima and Sumita26 proposed a probabilistic model for all the after-repair states called the generalized renewal process (GRP). Several papers have been published in recent years that extend this general (imperfect) repair model.27–31 The GRP approach was considered by Kaminskiy and Krivtsov 32 and they subsequently offered a Monte Carlo-based approximate solution for certain application areas.33According to this approach, the RP and the NHPP are considered specific cases of the generalized model.

A constant q may not be the case for some equipment and maintenance processes, but it is a reasonable approach for most repairable components and systems.

The described three models each have advantages and limitations. In general, the more realistic model will be the one that is more complex and complete in terms of its mathematical expression. The NHPP model has been proved to provide good results even for realistic situations with better-than-old but worse-than-new repairs.34

Based on the mentioned approaches, and given their conservative nature and manageable mathematical expressions, the methodology used in the case studies that will be presented concentrates on the NHPP because of its simplicity and for the following reasons.35

list-item.p: It is generally suitable for the purpose of modelling data with a trend, due to the fact that the accepted formats of the NHPP are monotonously increasing/decreasing functions.
NHPP models are mathematically straightforward and their theoretical basis is well developed.
Models have been tested fairly well, and several examples are available in the literature for their application.

sec.title: The NHPP model proposed for the evaluation of the costs per failure
sec.p: Most of the methodologies proposed in recent years include a basic analysis that allows the quantification of the economic impact generated by the failure of a production system.38 In relation to the quantification of the costs for non-reliability in the LCCA, in this article the use of a NHPP model is recommended. This model evaluates the impact of the main failures on the cost structure of a production system, starting from a simple process, which is summarized as: first, the most important types of failures are determined; then, assigned to each failure type is a constant value of occurrence frequency per year (this value will not change during the expected useful life); later on, the impact in cost per year is estimated, generated by the failures in the production, operations, environment and security; and finally, the total impact on cost of failures for the years of expected useful life is considered in the present value for a specific discount rate. sec.title: Development of case studies and comparison
sec.p: The following case studies show the evaluation of the economic impact of failures using the NHPP method. The analysis was developed for the oil company Petronox - Shell (Venezuela) and for the rail freight industry (Chile).

The maintenance strategy for both assets is time-based preventive maintenance: case 1: semi-annually and case 2: weekly. The MTTR was calculated including the corrective and preventive times for repair

sec.title: Case study 1: oil company
sec.p: This analysis was developed for the oil company Petronox - Shell (contractor of Petróleos of Venezuela), operating in the gas and petroleum field Naricual II in Monagas, Venezuela. In general terms, it is required to install a compression system to manage an average flow of 20,000,000 cubic feet of gas per day. option B: reciprocating compressor, 2810–3130 hp, flow: 20,000,000 cubic feet per day.

sec.title: Sensitivity analysis
sec.p: An important assessment for the case studies is a sensitivity analysis that considers the variation of the main variables (economic and/or technical data). For this particular analysis, as an example, variation in the costs of penalization for production loss and operational impact ($/hour) is considered.
A sensitivity analysis was performed for the rail freight industry – options A and B and the results are presented in Table 12 and Figure 4.

sec.p: With this analysis we can visualize how the costs of penalization for production loss and operational impact, which is part of the cost of failure, could lead to large variations in the total life cycle cost of the asset. sec.p: The following recommendations are made based on the obtained results.

list-item.p: It is recommended that Petronox takes into account the importance of the costs estimated to accrue as a result of failures and select option A since it offers a better economic return over the prospective lifespan.

If $5801 is a significant amount of money for the rail industry, the decision should be similar to the oil industry (select option A), which takes into account the economic consequences of failures. If the difference in money for both alternatives is not important, the decision will be taken based on qualitative factors such as:
professional relationship with the suppliers;

sec.p: Additionally, both organization, should design an internal procedure that allows evaluation of the costs of reliability, this procedure should then be used every time that different options for design, selection, substitution and/or purchase of assets for a process are analysed.

sec.title: General evaluation of the model
sec.p: The main strengths and weaknesses of this model can be summarized as follows.

list-item.p: The NHPP is one of the most popular models for repairable systems, so many models have been developed based on this process, such as the Crow-AMSAA model36 and bounded intensity process model. 39
It is a useful and quite simple model to represent equipment under ageing (deterioration) conditions.
It involves relatively simple mathematical expressions.
It is a conservative approach and in most cases provides results very similar to those of more complex models like GRP.40
Is not adequate to simulate repair actions that restore the unit to conditions better than new or worse than old.
This model does not consider the time-to-repair as an independent indicator to calculate the number of failures.

sec.title: Conclusions and future directions
sec.p: The orientation of this work is towards an analysis of the reliability factor and its impact on costs. This is a result of the fact that there is no easily applied evaluation procedure to rank the factors that affect reliability. In the process analysis of the costs along the life cycle of an asset, many decisions and actions exist that need to be taken, of particular interest for this work are those aspects related to the improvement process reliability (quality of the design, technology used, technical complexity, frequency of failures, costs of preventive/corrective maintenance, maintainability levels and accessibility). These factors have impact on the total cost of the life cycle of an asset, and they significantly influence the possible extent to which the useful life of the asset can be extended with reasonable costs. For these reasons, it is important to estimate the life cycle of the assets, to evaluate and to analyse in detail those aspects related with the failure rate. According to Weckman et al.20 the following points should be considered in failure rate trend analyses.

list-item.p: Failure of a component may be partial, and repair work done on a failed component may be imperfect. Therefore, the time periods between successive failures are not necessarily independent. This is a major source of trends in the failure rate.

Imperfect repairs performed following failures do not renew the system, i.e. the component will not be as good as new; only then can the statistical inference methods using a ROCOF assumption be used.

Repairs made by adjusting, lubricating or otherwise treating component parts that are wearing out provide only a small additional capability for further operation, and do not renew the component or system. These types of repair may result in a trend of an increasing ROCOF.
A component may fail more frequently due to ageing and wearing out.

sec.p: It is important to mention that for the LCCA technique a potential area of optimization related to the evaluation of the impact of reliability exists. In the near future new proposals on how to evaluate the costs generated by low reliability will use advanced mathematical methods such as:

list-item.p: stochastic methods;22,34,37,40,41–42
advanced maintenance optimization using genetic algorithms;43,44
Monte Carlo simulation techniques;45,46,32
advanced reliability distribution analyses;16,47–53
Markov simulation methods.54,55

sec.p: These methods will have their particular characteristics and their main objective is to diminish the uncertainty created in the estimation process of the total costs of an asset during its expected useful life cycle. It is not feasible to develop a unique LCCA model, which suits all of the requirements. However, it is possible to develop more elaborate models to address specific needs such as a reliability cost-effective asset development. See Table 14 for a list of the stochastic processes that can be used in the reliability analysis of repairable systems. Finally, it is important to mention that the results of the developed real case studies help in understanding and confirm the importance of the procedures that consider the economic impact of failures in life cycle analysis. This consideration will support the decision-making process.
